newsitem.title: CHINA: Chinese man makes mud map to mark return of HK.
newsitem.headline: Chinese man makes mud map to mark return of HK.

text.p: A man in China's northeastern Heilongjiang province has made a mud map of the country to express his excitement over the return of Hong Kong, the official Xinhua news agency said on Thursday.

Niu Shigang had left empty spaces in his 100-kg (220 lb) map for Beijing's island rival Taiwan, the Portuguese enclave of Macau and for Hong Kong, which reverts to Chinese control at midnight on June 30 after 156 years of British colonial rule.

He had toured China to gather soil samples for the map, which boasted earth from a ruined palace in Beijing that was burned by British and French soldiers last century, as well as soil from the hometown of late paramount leader Deng Xiaoping, Xinhua said.
"He hopes that some Hong Kong people can help him fill in the Hong Kong area gap with Hong Kong's soil on July 1," it said.
The map was currently hanging at the entrance of a park in the Heilongjiang provincial capital Harbin, it said.
Beijing has regarded Taiwan as a renegade province since Nationalist troops lost a civil war and took refuge on the island in 1949. Macau reverts to Chinese control in 1999.
